meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>box</radical> is open. There could be any number of things inside, but for now all you need to know is the meaning of this radical, which is box.

A (modified) prison radical containing a person radical. What does a person experience in prison? <radical>Lack</radical>. Prison is all about lack — lack of freedom, lack of the comforts of home, lack of privacy, lack of conversation. Yep, the life of a person in prison is defined by lack.

This is the <radical>stamp</radical> radical — the inking kind, not the postage kind. Why? Because it looks like a stamp stick! The top parts are thicker on one side so you can get a good grip. It even looks like the letter P — which just happens to be the last letter in "stamp"!

The radicals ground and big make up this radical. There's a big guy on the ground... who is that big guy? Embarrassingly, it's your <radical>husband</radical>. Feel the shame that he got knocked down on the ground. By what? Who? How? (It doesn't matter.)

Don't confuse this with 未 (jet), though. See how 未 has a little tail at the end? That's because jets and other planes have tails, while husbands don't. At least I'd sure hope yours doesn't.

Under a cliff, you spot a cross, slightly tilted. The cross is there to mark a famous <radical>clan</radical> that once ruled the lands below the cliff. It's a pretty unique cross, so whenever you see it there under the cliff, you'll know it honors the clan who lived there.
This looks like a <radical>boat</radical> coming toward you in the water. See the sail billowing on top and the reflection on the water? Yep, that's a boat. The boatiest boat that ever boated.
This is a <radical>fish</radical>. Kind of a funny-looking fish, with a weird head on top, a squat scaly body, and a tail fanning out underneath it. See the fish? Yeah, you see it.
See the cool wing on the bottom? See the head with the neat feather coming out of the top? This is a <radical>bird</radical>. Tweet tweet!

Flowers that grow out of the ground of a rice paddy after you bury fins there will grow <radical>yellow</radical>. Why? Because yellow is the color of a fish's soul, so planting flowers over their fins will turn them into a nice, pretty yellow.
If you boil a village, everything will turn <radical>black</radical>. Just imagine all those roads melting and coating everything in black tar. Picture it! It looks like Pompeii. (Oof, too soon?)

You take your head and pack clay dirt around it to just above your mouth. You need the <radical>circumference</radical> of your head for your helmet maker, and sending them a clay dirt mold of your head will just do the trick. That way they'll know your head's exact circumference!
See the <radical>wing</radical>? It's kind of like a bat wing with webbing. Either way, it's just a wing.
What happens when you put a flat surface on top of a pair of legs? You get a <radical>table</radical>.

This radical looks kind of like a <radical>temple</radical>, don't you think? With all the layers and stuff? Just picture the top part as a roof, and the drop-looking bit at the bottom as a giant temple bell, with a monk standing beside it and ringing it with a large wooden beam. You see this kinda thing every day at a temple.

This radical already looks like a <radical>gate</radical>, right? A high gate with pillars on either side and two small gate doors, way up at the top for some reason. Worst gate ever in terms of security, but definitely still a gate.
This kinda looks like a head with an arm under it pointing up at itself. That's why this radical means <radical>oneself</radical>. One points to oneself when one wants to… indicate oneself…

This is the radical for <radical>south</radical>. See how it's pointing south? You can think of the cross on top as a compass rose, and the arrow below (that ¥-looking part) as pointing down south. It's a compass pointing nowhere but south!

Who's in the coffin next to that child? It's his <radical>teacher</radical>. Teachers are pretty much dead around 3 p.m. every day, and it's the kids in their class who wear them down. It ain't easy being a teacher, you know.
This radical looks just like a top hat. That's why it's <radical>top hat</radical>!

This is an <radical>elephant</radical> — or at least, a wannabe elephant. Look closely. It's actually a family of pigs, and the mama is wearing an elephant mask on her head for some reason. See the big ears and trunk on top? She wants to be an elephant so badly that she dressed up like one.
